top_comment.text:
Little facts for the novices.
"Production car" yet they plan to produce only "10" per year,  check 
Bugatti company and see how many they produce per year across the world, 
Ahem.
I think they should do some business and learn what's real production is. 
Bugatti sold about 5 in it's 1st year and 44 in it's 2nd year and has 
maintained this production figure over the subsequent years.

Bugatti worked with NASA just for its tyre production, and the reason for 
its aerodynamic and weight is to increase deceleration during breaks, when 
we speak of bugatti as a fast car we speak of it as a "quality car"
And Koenigsegg follows that same very thought about their car 
production,The reason why so is that the heavier a car, the better 
deceleration and greater control can be achieved when gravity gains power 
as speed reduces, this is known as weight-shifting and it's very important 
for smooth driving. They never wanted to build ONLY the fastest cars, they 
wanted to build FAST but also drive-ready car which won't cause trouble on 
the road.

The same can't be said about Hennessy Venom GT which looks like a car with 
weight removal, tuned up engine , The wheel is racing spec with no over 
layers just for the sake of weight reduction to gain than 1 mph over the 
bugatti veyron. 

Theoretically speaking for a car to be driven 'safely' above 240mph, it 
needs to have about 1.300-1.400 Kg. I think the american producer didn't 
bother about security unlike sweden and german did.

So basically what i'm saying 

Bugatti Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse  - All Drive-able fast car - 2nd fastest 
acceleration to Hennessy Venom GT, very good handling and brake technology. 
Kerb weight 1,800 kg                                                       
                                            Has undergone NASA test and 
weight shifting test to ensure it will become the world drive-all  fastest 
car. if they now wanted to make it a racing spec
                                                                    that 
car wouldn't even be at 1,800 kg :)  See 1st PS3 and 2nd version of PS3? ok 
good.

Koenigsegg Agera R - All Drive-able fast car -  Relatively good 
acceleration still even a Zonda has a better acceleration than this car- 
Possibly have the highest top speed due to its unique 8 engine symmetry, 
gear clench but that's why it does also fall a bit behind in acceleration , 
good handling Kerb weight  1.400 kg. Koenigsegg company never really took 
part into Guinness world record set, but the fact still remains, this car 
has the highest top speed and this is a generally agree by everyone even 
there's no Guinness record about it.

Hennessy Venom GT -  "Concept" and "TUNED" car -  Fastest  acceleration 
1mph above Bugatti - No quality investment in brake system , lack of weight 
1,200 kg, has actually undergone 
weight reduction for 'RACING SPEC' to achieve this speed, using FOREIGN 
engine  ADDED superchargers to make it beat Bugatti by just 1mph. 

So "Fastest Tuned Car' , since Bugatti and Koenigsegg never really bother 
themselves to tune their quality car to beat that Venom GT but taking the 
fact as it is 1mph is really nothing, it's actually funny. 
 


 ﻿

Been doing my homework since I changed my view recently.... only too find 
out that I never should have.

He just said it himself..... 3:15 to 3:30 "no modifications, no 
alterations, and it has to be a PRODUCTION CAR that's in factory mod." The 
Guinness official himself called it a production vehicle, to this day, they 
do indeed consider it a production vehicle by Guinness specifications.

Watch the video of it's record top speed run and you can see and tell where 
the driver had to let off on the two mile runway he had, with a very clear 
amount of power still at the rear wheels. Meaning this production vehicle 
made it to 265.7mph in LESS than 2 miles, and made it to 186.411mph in 
13.18seconds. averaged by Guinness with a 14.08second run to 13.63 seconds, 
a full second faster than the Agera R. To say the Bugatti is a superior 
still is foolish. With a 2 wheel (rear wheel) drive vehicle that has a true 
actual manual (not dual-clutch not some nonsense two key special advance 
start system) with half of pretty much everything doing damn near the same 
thing in less than half the pavement. How can you truly believe that this 
car has no bearing on the Veyron? Bugatti wouldn't allow them to test on 
the 4 mile stretch the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Super Sport did (mind you after 
they took the limiter off and somehow managed to get Guinness to say it was 
still factory and untouched). Can you imagine why? If it can do 2 mph less 
than the Bugatti in less than half the distance, imagine what it could do 
in the full distance. 

Sway me otherwise. ﻿

computers do most of the work nowadays. I do agree that the stock 1.8L 
Toyota 2zz is very underpowered, but it is fairly easy to get more power

corvette engine.

When these fat jokers pat eachothers backs and pay Guinness Book of Records 
to witness a record attempt... They PAY Guinness Book of Records to show 
up. And they get their picture taken, they get their diploma and their 
plaque which says Guinness Book of Records witnessed the event and blah 
blah blah... Essentially they get what they paid for.

But the dude that shows up is not a car expert. They just send over a 
gentleman with a tie and a flipchart to witness the event. That does NOT 
mean it actually goes into the Guinness Book of Records as a valid record.

SSC Aero also claimed to have the fastest "production" car in the world. 
but it soon turned out to be a steel tubular kit-car based on a Lamborghini 
Diablo replica kit with bits and peaces off other production cars. They 
claimed to be in the Guinness Book of Records too. And while its true that 
Guinness showed up and witnessed their run, they never put it into the 
actual records book because they dont allow kit-cars to pass as 
"production" cars.

In the event of any discrepancy of what is and isnt a "production car" 
Guinness has their own rule of atleast 20 must be made... Which none of 
these qualify for anyway. ﻿

I wouldn't say it isn't American. The only thing that makes it special is 
its firebreathing engine, which is 100% American. It's basically an 
American engine on wheels. Also, it wouldn't exist were it not for John 
Hennessey coming up with the idea. So there's that, too.

"Supercar" is a vague word. I however would classify the Venom GT as a 
supercar. I mean, a lightweight, streetable car with 1200+ hp, a top speed 
greater than that of any other car you can really buy. Sounds super to me.

Whether or not it's a production car is a legitimate question. I have heard 
conflicting reports on what is required to be a production car. Frankly, I 
don't give a shit. It's fast as hell, that's all it does for me.
comments.author: Drew Keefe

comments.text:
+Drew Keefe And still... Quite clearly a hell of alot of people DO care. 
Which is why I say these things. To clarify how this thing ISNT american, 
ISNT a supercar and ISNT a production car. Therefore, no matter how fast it 
goes, CANNOT hold records reserved for production cars.

Infact there is no such thing as a Hennessey Venom GT at all. Aslong as its 
registered as a Lotus. Running Lotus license plates, Lotus paperwork, And 
aslong as its still running Lotus VIN / Chassis number.
comments.author: Janusha

comments.text:
+Janusha
"Quite clearly people do care... Including you."

Ahh, the old "Well you must care because you commented" logic. Wonderful. 
Unfortunately for you, I couldn't care less whether or not the Venom GT is 
a production car. I will never own one. I think it's a beast of a car, and 
I would love to drive it at some point. But beyond that, my interest peaks.

I should have worded my original comment differently, looking back. Replace 
"no one cares" with "it doesn't matter", and you have what I meant to say.
comments.author: Drew Keefe

comments.text:
+LeocornoProductions
No no no. Hennessey first said they would make 50. Now they are saying they 
will build 29. But it doesnt matter what they like to claim. They havent 
even made 12 and they are already talking (bullshit) about making an even 
faster, even more powerful thing. Will they ever make 30 ? I doubt it.

But even if they make a car for each household in america, its STILL a god 
damn Lotus with a Corvette engine. What part of this is hard for you to 
understand ?

If america wants to be in the game, they need to stop CLAIMING and start 
DOING. Stard building their own god damn cars. Since the 60s Ford GT and AC 
Cobra, americas 2 largest car icons, that were just like the Hennessey god 
damn Venom, they were just British cars with american engines.

Simply CLAIMED to be american in a time when people couldnt look shit up on 
the net. Well today you dont get away with that shit anymore and america 
never ONCE built their own production supercar.

comments.text:
+Alexander Young
The Guinness Book of Records get confused some times because these lying 
jokers of the car industry TELL them they are selling production cars when 
they really arent.

On the other hand... Guinness is a book publisher and not car experts. They 
certainly are no government agency that can make a car "production" or not. 
They have their own criterias and their own rules but at the end of the 
day, they also have to sell those books. Even to americans. And they wont 
sell many books to americans by being strict with their silly little 
kit-cars that they hail to the skies as if they really were the real deal.

Many people dont like what I say about these things or how I say it.. But 
over the discussions above, Ive explained what is and isnt a "production" 
car in great detail. Go forth and read up. I atleast try to keep it fairly 
entertaining.
comments.author: Janusha

captions.text: [CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: What has driven us
to transform the car into a

violent space capsule whose
abilities require several
acres of empty tarmac?

You can't measure certain cars
today by their 0-60 time.

That's a carrier pigeon
in the age of iPhones.

The new ruler requires
a runway.

It's the same reason we went
from the Wright Brothers to

NASA, from canoe to
aircraft carrier.

Because we, as people,
have a drive to take
something and master it.

And although we've conquered the
gasoline engine, extracted

every last iota of explosive
power, in the modern day we

are simply limited
by adhesion.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: Going for a Guinness
record is not as
simple as it sounds.

All the right pieces must fit
together all at once.

For the team at Hennessey,
the process began
almost five years ago.

If there's one thing Hennessey
knows, it's horsepower--
so that wasn't a problem.

Its twin-turbo, 7.0-litre V8
makes 1,244 horsepower and

over 1,000 pound
feet of torque.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: Second pull, 995
at the wheels, so that's
medium boost.

So it sounds like it's breaking
up because at the top

of fourth gear he's spinning
the tires on the dyno.
JOHN HENNESSEY: Exactly.

MATT FARAH: So you're getting
wheel spin in fourth at
150-miles an hour.
JOHN HENNESSEY: Yeah.

The traction control, obviously,
is turned off.

I mean, the car came in from the
pouring rainstorm and the

tires are soaked in water
and the [INAUDIBLE]
are wet.

MATT FARAH: So even with wheel
spin, that's not enough
[INAUDIBLE].

JOHN HENNESSEY: We may not be
able to get it to hook-up on
the dyno today.

Hopefully it's dry on
the runway tomorrow.
MATT FARAH: Yeah.

Finding a balance of
aerodynamics and plenty of

down force without ruining the
Lotus' already attractive
shape is no small task.

So many factors, all of which
come together on one day, are

the culmination of a man's
five-year-long dream to build
the fastest road car on earth.

This road missile, though it
may be street-legal, is
basically a race car.

A no-frills merchant of death,
ready to remind you that

nothing will ever
feel fast again.

PHILIP ROBERTSON: No
modifications, no alterations,

and it has to be a production
car with some factory
modifications at maximum.

And the tires also have
to be DOT standard.

The attempt must be supervised
by a national or international

testing agency for motorized
vehicles, which we have here.

The VBox 3I GPS unit is going
to be used to give us the

accurate speed of
these vehicles.

And we've had the circuit
approved as being flat and

level, so there's no
advantage there.

To ensure there's no advantage
for wind, we have to take a

final figure from an average
of two runs in opposite

directions down the same
circuit, just so that we have

a completely legitimate
attempt.

The existing record for the
fastest 0-300 by a production

car was set by the Koenigsegg
Agera R at 14.53 seconds.

We've got an extremely fast car
behind us, so I'm excited
to see how this goes.

I've got a sneaking suspicion
this is going to go well

today, but that's all
I'm going to say.

JOHN HENNESSEY: The city of
Houston and the airport

system's kind enough to
let us have access to
one of their runways.

We have basically an
8,000-foot-long runway that

we're able to run about 7,500
feet on that runway.

And we're here today to see what
our seventh production

Venom GT is capable of running
from zero, potentially up to
250 miles per hour.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
So we're a second and a half.

PHILIP ROBERTSON: He can still
go 14-14.2 in the opposite
direction and still beat it.
-Yeah.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

JOHN HENNESSEY: I think
on our 0-300K we
were around 14 seconds.

So that would average out about
a second faster than the
existing record.

DON GOLDMAN: Philip,
would you agree?

PHILIP ROBERTSON:
I would concur.

That's a new Guinness
World Record.
[APPLAUSE]
DON GOLDMAN: That's great.
JOHN HENNESSEY: Partner.

PHILIP ROBERTSON: That
was stunning.
Congratulations, Don.
DON GOLDMAN: Thank you.
PHILIP ROBERTSON: Phenomenal.

JOHN HENNESSEY: Let me
tell you something.

The Venom GT's a fast
car-- one of the
fastest cars in the world.
And today it's the fastest from
0-300K, thank you, Guinness.

But none of that would be
possible without this guy

Don Goldman is the man behind

makes the engine go.
DON GOLDMAN: Thank you, John.
And Kevin who helped us.
JOHN HENNESSEY: Absolutely.

PHILIP ROBERTSON: You guys, for
the record, all of that

all of that work, that grit,

that determination, that

JOHN HENNESSEY: Just think of

MATT FARAH: The world of hyper

And the Wira, the modern

We said it last time and we'll

And according to Guinness,
